title: main
section: Robust Localization w.r.t. Power Lines in Sparse Environments
text:
Robust Localization w.r.t. Power Lines in Sparse Environments



The ground has a uniform texture.
There are too few utility poles or immediate fences.
There are no trees or other geometries.
GPS provides absolute position, need relative pose to power lines!















Insufficient landmarks


Any vision-based estimation mechanism will not perform reliably and robustly for drone localization.











Electromagnetic field around the power lines


If we can get reliable measurements, then we can devise a distance and bearing factor exploiting this field.

title: main
section: Electric and Magnetic Field around Three-Phase Power Lines
text:
Electric and Magnetic Field around Three-Phase Power Lines





EM Field near Three-Phase Power Lines


Quasi-static approximation to Maxwell‚Äôs equations yields (\(\mathbf{q} = (x, z)\) is the location of the sensor)
\[
\bar{E}^2(\mathbf{q}) = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{\alpha=1}^3\left(e_\alpha^2 -
\sum_{\alpha^\prime > \alpha}^3 c_{\alpha\alpha^\prime}e_\alpha e_{\alpha^\prime} \right),
\]
where \(e_\alpha = \frac{\xi}{r_\alpha} = \frac{\beta c \mu_0 I_0}{2\pi}\frac{1}{r_\alpha}\) is the peak electric field magnitude and \(c_{\alpha\alpha^\prime} = \cos{\left(\theta_\alpha - \theta_{\alpha^\prime}\right)}\).













From total rms energy considerations, it can be shown that \(\bar{B} = \sqrt{\mu_0 \varepsilon_0} \bar{E}\).

title: main
section: Gradient of the Electric Field around Three-Phase Power Lines

title: main
section: Navigating the Drone to One of the Power Lines
text:
Navigating the Drone to One of the Power Lines





Potential Function and its Gradient


Define the potential function \(V(\mathbf{q}) = \frac{1}{\bar{E}^2(\mathbf{q})}\). Its gradient is \[
\nabla_{\mathbf{q}}V(\mathbf{q}) = -\frac{2}{\bar{E}^3}\nabla_{\mathbf{q}}\bar{E}(\mathbf{q})
\] Further, \(\lVert \nabla_{\mathbf{q}}V(\mathbf{q}) \rVert = O\left(\frac{1}{\bar{E}}\right)\) as \(\bar{E} \rightarrow \infty\) (or \(r_\alpha \rightarrow 0\)).






Lemma: Critical points of \(V(\mathbf{q})\)



Generically \(V\) has \(5\) isolated critical points, \(3\) of which are global minima and have \(r_\alpha = 0\).
Applying Poincar√©-Hopf theorem on the convex hull of the power lines yields the remaining 2 are saddle points!









Following \(\nabla_{\mathbf{q}}V(\mathbf{q})\) navigates the drone to one of the power lines.

title: main
section: Robust Localization with GTSAM: Sensor Fusion Library
text:
Robust Localization with GTSAM: Sensor Fusion Library



Factors depict constaints on the poses as:

prior state: \(f_0(x_1)\)
odometry relation: \(f_i(x_i, x_{i+1}; o_i)\)
observations: \(f_i(x_i;z_i)\).






\[
\begin{aligned}
p(\mathbf{x} | \mathbf{o}) \propto p(x_1) \prod_{i=2}^{3} p(x_i | x_{i-1}, o_i)\\
% f(\mathbf{x}) = \arg\max_{\mathbf{x}}  f_0(x_1) \prod_{i=1}^{2} f_i(x_i, x_{i+1}; o_i)
\end{aligned}
\]



\[
\begin{aligned}
p(\mathbf{x} | \mathbf{o}, \mathbf{z}) \propto p(x_1) \prod_{i=2}^{3} p(x_i | x_{i-1}, o_i) p(z_i | x_i) \\
% f(\mathbf{x}) = \arg\max_{\mathbf{x}}  f_0(x_1) \prod_{i=1}^{2} f_i(x_i, x_{i+1}; o_i)  g_i(x_i; z_i)
\end{aligned}
\]



\[
\begin{aligned}
p(\mathbf{x} | \mathbf{o}, \mathbf{l}) \propto p(x_1) \prod_{i=2}^{3} p(x_i | x_{i-1}, o_i) p(l_i | x_i) \\
% f(\mathbf{x}) = \arg\max_{\mathbf{x}}  f_0(x_1) \prod_{i=1}^{2} f_i(x_i, x_{i+1}; o_i)  h_i(x_i; l_i)
\end{aligned}
\]

title: main
section: GTSAM meets Gradient of the Electric Field
text:
GTSAM meets Gradient of the Electric Field





\(\nabla_{\mathbf{q}}\bar{E}(\mathbf{q})\) points towards the convex hull


The unit vector along this gradient may be used as a bearing factor in GTSAM at any point \(\mathbf{q}\) during navigation!

Turns the convex hull of the power lines into a landmark.

title: main
text:
Dissipativity

A dynamical system
\[
\Sigma: \quad
\begin{cases}
  \dot{x} &= f(x,u) \\
  y &= h(x,u)
\end{cases}
\quad x \in \mathcal{X} \subset \mathbb{R}^{2n}, \, u \in \mathcal{U} \subset \mathbb{R}^{m}
\]
is dissipative with respect to some supply rate \(s\) if there exists a storage function \(\mathcal{H}: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}^{+}\) such that
\[
\mathcal{H}\left(  x(t_1) \right) \leq  \mathcal{H}\left(  x(t_0) \right) + \int_{t_0}^{t_1} s(u(t), y(t)) \, \text{d}t
\]
for all \(x(t_0) = x_0\), all input \(u\), and all \(t_1 \geq t_0\)

title: main
text:
Dissipativity and Passivity
\[
\mathcal{H}\left(  x(t_1) \right) \leq  \mathcal{H}\left(  x(t_0) \right) + \int_{t_0}^{t_1} s(u(t), y(t)) \, \text{d}t
\]



Dissipation Inequality



Stored energy at \(t_1\) is at most equal to stored energy at \(t_0\), plus externally supplied energy \(s(u,y)\).
No generation of energy, only internal dissipation.








Passivity


The system \(\Sigma\) is passive if it is dissipative with supply rate
\[s = u^\top y.\]
It is output strictly passive if it is dissipative with supply rate
\[s = u^\top y - \delta \lVert y \rVert^2, \; \delta > 0.\]
It is input strictly passive if it is dissipative with supply rate
\[s = u^\top y - \delta \lVert u \rVert^2, \; \delta > 0.\]

title: main
text:
Stability of Passive Systems

\[
\Sigma: \quad
\begin{cases}
  \dot{x} &= f(x,u), && f(0,0) = 0, \\
  y &= h(x,u), && h(0,0) = 0,
\end{cases}
\]
\(u^{\top} y \geq \dot{\mathcal{H}} = \frac{\partial\mathcal{H}}{\partial x} f(x,u),\quad \mathcal{H} \geq 0,\quad y \equiv 0 \implies x \equiv 0\)



Lemma (Khalil, 2002)


The origin of \(\Sigma\) is:

stable if \(\Sigma\) is passive,
asymptotically stable if \(\Sigma\) is output strictly passive,
globally asymptotically stable if \(\Sigma\) is output strictly passive and the storage function \(\mathcal{H}(x) \to \infty\) as \(\lVert x \rVert \to \infty\) (radially unbounded)






Notice that we only require that the function \(\mathcal{H}\) be positive semidefinite and not necessarily positive definite as per usual Lyapunov conditions.
Observability (detectability) ensures LaSalle‚Äôs theorem works.

title: main
text:
Passivity-Based Control (PBC)

\[
\Sigma_o: \quad
\begin{cases}
  \dot{x} &= f(x) + g(x)u, \\
  y &= h(x)
\end{cases}
\]
Main idea ‚Äî Select \(u(x) = u_{es} + u_{di}\) that renders the closed-loop system passive.
\[
\Sigma_d: \quad
\begin{cases}
  \dot{x} &= f_d(x) + g(x) u_{di}, \quad f_d := f(x) + g(x) u_{es}(x) \\
  y_d &= h_d(x)
\end{cases}
\]
Control problem is cast as a search for \(H_d\) and \(h_d\) s.t. \(\dot{H}_d \leq y_d^\top u_{di}\)

title: main
text:
PBC Example - Simple Pendulum




System Dynamics


\(H(q,p) = \frac{1}{2} J^{-1} p^2 + mgl (1 - \cos q)\)
\[
\begin{bmatrix} \dot{q} \\ \dot{p} \end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix} \phantom{-}0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix} \nabla_q H_{\phantom{d}} \\ \nabla_p H_{\phantom{d}} \end{bmatrix} +
\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ G \end{bmatrix} u_\phantom{di},
\qquad y = \dot{q}
\]

Choose \(u = u_{es} + u_{di}\) that transforms system into a passive one with \(x^\star = (q^\star, 0)\) 


\(Gu_{es} = \nabla_q H  - \nabla_q H_d , \quad Gu_{di} = -GK_D G^\top \nabla_p H_d\)



\[
\begin{bmatrix} \dot{q} \\ \dot{p} \end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix} \phantom{-}0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix} \nabla_q H_d \\ \nabla_p H_d \end{bmatrix} +
\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ G \end{bmatrix} u_{di},
\qquad y = \dot{q}
\]


\[
\begin{bmatrix} \dot{q} \\ \dot{p} \end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix} \phantom{-}0 & 1 \\ -1 & -G K_D G^\top \end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix} \nabla_q H_d \\ \nabla_p H_d \end{bmatrix},
\qquad y = \dot{q}
\]

title: main
text:
PBC Example - Simple Pendulum




Control Synthesis via PBC


Choose \(u = u_{es} + u_{di}\) that transforms system into a passive one with \(x^\star =  (q^\star, 0)\)
\(Gu_{es} = \nabla_q H  - \nabla_q H_d , \quad Gu_{di} = -GK_D G^\top \nabla_p H_d\)
\[
\begin{bmatrix} \dot{q} \\ \dot{p} \end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix} \phantom{-}0 & 1 \\ -1 & -G K_D G^\top \end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix} \nabla_q H_d \\ \nabla_p H_d \end{bmatrix},
\qquad y = \dot{q}
\]

\(H_d(q,p) = \frac{1}{2} J^{-1} p^2 + V_d(q), \quad V_d(q) = \frac{1}{2} K_{P} \left( q - q^\star \right)^2\)



\(\dot{H}_d = -K_D \left( J^{-1} p \right)^2 = y^\top u_{di} \leq 0\)


\(\boxed{u = -mgl\sin(x) - K_P(q - q^\star) - K_D \dot{q}}\)

title: main
text:
Motivation

Control synthesis in PBC: \[
Gu_{es} = \nabla_q H - \nabla_q H_d
\]

If underactuated, \(G\) is not invertible

Choice of \(u_{es}\) must satisfy nonlinear PDE
Quadratic potential most likely not viable

Incorporate performance objective into design of \(H_d\)?

title: main
text:
NeuralPbc Problem Statement

Consider the mechanical system
\[
\begin{bmatrix} \dot{q} \\ \dot{p} \end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix} \phantom{-}0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix} \nabla_q H_{\phantom{d}} \\ \nabla_p H_{\phantom{d}} \end{bmatrix} +
\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ G \end{bmatrix} u_\phantom{di}
\]
Control task: stabilize desired equilibrium \(x^\star = (q^\star, 0)\)


\[u = u_{es} + u_{di} = G^{\dagger} \left( \nabla_q H  - \nabla_q H_d \right)  - K_D G^\top \nabla_p H_d \]


\[u = u_{es} + u_{di} = - G^{\dagger} \nabla_q H_d^{\theta}  - K_D G^\top \nabla_p H_d^{\theta} \]


Choosing a suitable \(H_d\) is not trivial

Parameterize \(H_d\) by a neural network \(H_d^\theta\), and relax control task to bringing \(x\) to a small neighborhood of \(x^\star\)



Instead of asking for asymptotic stabilization, we only require that trajectories pass thru a nbhd of \(x^\star\)
This is reasonable because we know how to stabilize a fixed point, e.g.¬†stabilize the linearization of the system using LQR
This allows us to find approximations for \(H_d^\theta\) using learning techniques

title: main
main
text:
NeuralPbc Loss Function

\[
J(\theta, x_0) = \int_{0}^{T} \ell \left(\phi,u^\theta,\theta\right)\, \text{d} t
\]
\(\ell \triangleq \ell_{\text{set}}(\gamma) + \ell_{\bot}(\gamma,u)\) where

\(\phi\) is the flow of the equation of motion
\(\gamma\) is the closed-loop trajectory starting from \(x_0\)
\(T\) is the time horizon (hyperparameter)

title: main
text:
NeuralPbc Loss Function

\[\ell \triangleq \ell_{\text{set}}(\gamma) + \ell_{\bot}(\gamma,u)\]



Set Distance Loss \(\ell_{\text{set}}\)


Penalizes when closed-loop trajectory \(\gamma\) under the current control law is far away from a neighborhood \(\mathcal{S}\) of \(x^\star\)






\[\ell_{\text{set}}(x) = \underset{t}{\inf} \left\{ \lVert a-b \rVert : a \in \gamma(t), b \in \mathcal{S}\right\}\] * The set \(\mathcal{S}\) may be chosen as * A ball around \(x^\star\) * Estimated region of attraction * No additional loss if any point in \(\gamma\) is in \(\mathcal{S}\)

title: main
text:
NeuralPbc Loss Function

\[\ell \triangleq \ell_{\text{set}}(\gamma) + \ell_{\bot}(\gamma,u)\]



Transversal Distance Loss \(\ell_{\bot}\)


Measures how close \(\gamma\) is to \(\gamma^\star\) (expert trajectory) using transverse coordinates \(x_\bot\)







Coordinate transformation

\(\tau \in \mathbb{R}\) a surrogate for time
\(x_{\bot} \in \mathbb{R}^{2n-1}\) quantify how far away the current state is from \(\gamma^\star\)

By construction \(x_{\bot} \to 0 \iff \gamma = \gamma^\star\)

\[\ell_{\bot} = x_\bot^\top Q x_\bot + u^\top R u, \, Q \succeq 0, \, R \succ 0\]

No preferred orbit? \(Q = 0\)









We can find a coordinate transformation such that 1 coordinate \(\tau\) is along the desired orbit and acts as surrogate for time
The remaining coordinates \(x_{\bot}\) quantify how far away the current state is from the desired trajectory

title: main
text:
Backprop through ODE Solutions

We need \(\partial J / \partial \theta\), which depends ODE solutions

üòø Combining autodiff with numerical ODE solvers


üòø Adjoint sensitivity method: solve the adjoint problem backward in time \[\frac{\text{d}\lambda}{\text{d}t} = -\lambda \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}, \quad \frac{\partial J}{\partial \theta} = \lambda(t_0) \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\]


üò∫ Adjoint methods + autodiff implemented in DiffEqFlux.jl



Plain autodiff causes errors due to numerical ODE integration, high memory consumption
Adjoint methods requires storing many passes of the adjoint problem, again high memory consumption
DiffEqFlux combines the two, avoiding multiple passes through clever implementation, fast an efficient

title: main
text:
NeuralPbc Sampling State Space

Learned policy \(u^\theta\) need to perform well for a wide range of \(x_0\)


\[J(\theta, x_0) = \int_{0}^{T} \ell \left(\phi,u^\theta,\theta\right)\, \text{d} t\]



\[J(\theta) = \mathbb{E}_{x_0 \sim p(\mathbf{x}_0)} \left[ \int_{0}^{T} \ell \left(\phi(t,x_0),u^\theta,\theta\right)\, \text{d} t \right]\]


Sample state space with technique based on DAgger1


Simulating system under application of \(u^\theta\)
Collect samples from the regions of state-space visited by \(u^\theta\)




Use dynamics to guide the collection of samples


Ross, S., Gordon, G. J., & Bagnell, J. A. (2011). No-regret reductions for imitation learning and structured prediction. In AISTATS.

title: main
text: NeuralPbc Algorithm üìâ

title: main
text:
Bayesian Solution

¬†

Computing ELBO \[ \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D};z) = \mathbb{E}_{\theta \sim q}\left[ \log p(\mathcal{D} \mid \theta)p(\theta) - \log q(\theta; z)  \right] \] requires: ¬†

Likelihood: \[ p\left( \lVert \ell_{\text{set}}(\gamma) + \ell_\bot(\gamma, u) \rVert^2 \mid \theta \right) = \mathcal{N}(0, s). \]


Prior:


Uninformed


Deterministic

title: main
text:
Learned storage function



Observations

\(H_d^\theta\) has a local minimum at \(x^\star\), control law \(u^\theta\) commands the force in the expected direction

title: main
text:
Comparison with Energy Shaping1


K. J. √Östr√∂m and K. Furuta, ‚ÄúSwinging up a pendulum by energy control,‚Äù Automatica, vol.¬†36, no. 2, pp.¬†287‚Äì295, 2000.

title: main
text:
Motivation

NeuralPbc is flexible, but guaranteeing stability is hard
Additional structure of IdaPbc facilitates stability analysis


\[ \begin{bmatrix} \dot{q} \\ \dot{p} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}0 & I \\ -I & 0\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \nabla_q H \\ \nabla_p H  \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ G \end{bmatrix} u \] 
Closed-loop port-Hamiltonian dynamics:

\[
\begin{bmatrix} \dot{q} \\ \dot{p} \end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}0 & M^{-1}M_d \\ -M_dM^{-1} & J_2(q,p) - GK_vG^\top\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix} \nabla_q H_d \\ \nabla_p H_d \end{bmatrix}
\]  
\(H_d = \frac{1}{2} p^{\top} M_d(q)^{-1} p + V_d(q),\, M_d \succ 0\)


Further structure not only facilitates stability analysis but also restricts the search to a pd matrix \(M_d\) and \(V_d\).
This search may be performed solely on the configuration space.

title: main
text:
IdaPbc Background

\[ \begin{bmatrix} \dot{q} \\ \dot{p} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}0 & M^{-1}M_d \\ -M_dM^{-1} & J_2(q,p) - GK_vG^\top\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \nabla_q H_d \\ \nabla_p H_d \end{bmatrix} \]
\(H_d = \frac{1}{2} p^{\top} M_d(q)^{-1} p + V_d(q),\, M_d \succ 0\)






Stability results


\[\begin{aligned}\dot{H}_d &= \left( \nabla_p H_d \right)^{\top} \left(-G K_v G^{\top}\right) \nabla_p H_d \\ &\leq -\lambda_{\textrm{min}} \{ K_v \} \left\| \left( \nabla_p H_d \right)^{\top} G \right\|^2 \leq 0 \end{aligned}\]
With \(q^\star = \arg \min V_d(q)\), we have \(x \to x^\star = (q^\star, 0)\)








Control synthesis


Choose \(u = u_{es} + u_{di}\) where \[
\begin{aligned}
Gu_{es} &= \nabla_{q} H - M_{d}M^{-1} \nabla_{q} H_{d} \\
&\quad\; + J_{2} M_{d}^{-1} p \phantom{\nabla_{p}^{\top}} \\
u_{di} &= -K_v G^\top \nabla_p H_d \phantom{\left\|\left(\nabla_p\right)^{\top} \right\|^2}
\end{aligned}
\]

title: main
text:
IdaPbc via Optimization




¬†





\[
\begin{aligned}
\underset{M_d,\,J_2,\,V_d}{\text{minimize}} && 0 &  \\
\text{subject to} &&
0 &= G^{\bot}\left\{ \nabla_{q} H - M_{d}M^{-1} \nabla_{q} H_{d} + J_{2} M_{d}^{-1} p  \right\}
\\
&& H_d &= \frac{1}{2} p^{\top} M_d(q)^{-1} p + V_d(q)
\\
&& M_d &= M_d^\top \succ 0
\\
&& J_2 &= -J_2^\top
\\
&& q^\star &= \underset{q}{\arg \min} \, V_d(q)
\end{aligned}
\]





¬†




Infinite-dimensional‚Äîclosed-form solution is difficult

title: main
text: NeuralIdaPbc

title: main
text:
NeuralIdaPbc Problem Statement




¬†





\[
\begin{aligned}
\underset{\theta}{\text{minimize}} && J(\theta) &= \left\lVert G^{\bot} \left\{ \nabla_{q} H - M_{d}^{\theta}M^{-1} \nabla_{q} H_{d}^{\theta} + J_{2}^{\theta} \left(M_{d}^{\theta}\right)^{-1} p \right\} \right\rVert^2  \\
\text{subject to}
&& H_d^{\theta} &= \frac{1}{2} p^{\top} \left( M_{d}^{\theta} \right)^{-1} p + V_{d}^{\theta}(q)
\\
&& M_d^{\theta}(q) &= \left(M_d^{\theta}(q)\right)^\top \succ 0
\\
&& J_{2}^{\theta}(q,p) &= -\left(J_{2}^{\theta}(q,p)\right)^\top
\\
&& q^\star &= \underset{q}{\arg \min} \, V_{d}^{\theta} (q)
\end{aligned}
\]





¬†







Finite-dimensional search
Sample configuration space



¬†



Controller \(u\) is a continuous function of \(J\)

title: main
text:
NeuralIdaPbc Constraints


\[M_d^{\theta} = \left(M_d^{\theta}\right)^{\top} \succ 0\]


\[J_{2}^{\theta} = -\left(J_{2}^{\theta}\right)^{\top}\]
\[q^\star = \underset{q}{\arg \min} \, V_{d}^{\theta} (q)\]





Positive-definiteness of the desired mass matrix



Cholesky decomposition \(M_d^\theta(q) = L_{\theta}(q) L_{\theta}^{\top}(q)\)
Components of the lower-triangular matrix \(L_\theta(q)\) are outputs of a neural network

title: main
text:
NeuralIdaPbc Constraints


\[M_d^{\theta} = \left(M_d^{\theta}\right)^{\top} \succ 0\]


\[J_{2}^{\theta} = -\left(J_{2}^{\theta}\right)^{\top}\]


\[q^\star = \underset{q}{\arg \min} \, V_{d}^{\theta} (q)\]





Skew symmetry of \(J_2^\theta(q,p)\)



Decompose a square matrix into symmetric and skew-symmetric parts \[J_2^\theta(q,p) = A_{\theta}(q,p) -  A_{\theta}^{\top}(q,p)\]
Components of the square matrix \(A_\theta(q,p)\) are output of a neural network

title: main
text:
NeuralIdaPbc Constraints


\[M_d^{\theta} = \left(M_d^{\theta}\right)^{\top} \succ 0\] \[J_{2}^{\theta} = -\left(J_{2}^{\theta}\right)^{\top}\]


\[q^\star = \underset{q}{\arg \min} \, V_{d}^{\theta} (q)\]





Boundedness of \(V_d^\theta\)



\(V_d^\theta(q)\) bounded from below with isolated minimum at \(q^\star\) 
Parameterize \(V_d^\theta\) by a sums-of-square (SoS) polynomial
\(V_d^\theta(q) > 0,\, q \neq q^\star\)

title: main
text:
SoS Decomposition




Theorem (Choi, 1995)


A polynomial \(P \in \mathbb{R}[x]\) of degree \(2d\) has a SoS decomposition \(\Leftrightarrow\) \(\exists Q \succ 0\) such that, with \(\mu(x) = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & x_1 & \cdots & x_n & x_1 x_2 & \cdots & x_n^d\end{bmatrix}\), we have \(P(x) = \mu(x)^\top Q \mu(x)\)







Example


\[\begin{aligned} x_1^2 + 2x_1^2x_2 + 5x_1^2x_2^2 + 4x_1x_2^2 + x_2^2  &= \mu(x)^{\top} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 5 & 2 \\ 0 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \mu(x) \\ &= \mu(x)^{\top} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}   1 & 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}^{\top} \mu(x) \end{aligned} \]

title: main
text: Ball-beam experiments

title: main
text:
Robustness via Bayesian Learning





NeuralPbc assumes a nominal model \(\dot{x} = f_p(x, u)\)
The trained controller must not overfit on the observations generated from the nominal model









Our method: \(H_d\) is a Bayesian neural network

achieves the performance objective for samples \(\theta \sim P(\theta | \mathbb{D})\)
searches for ensemble of parameters that meet the desired performance \[
  P(\theta \mid \mathbb{D}) = \frac{\overbrace{P(\mathbb{D} \mid
  \theta)}^{\text{likelihood}}\overbrace{P(\theta)}^{\text{prior}}}
  {\underbrace{\int_\theta P(\mathbb{D} \mid \theta^\prime)P(\theta^\prime)
  d\theta^\prime}_{\text{evidence}}}.
\]

title: main
text:
Training Stochastic Models






Bayesian Inference


\[
\begin{aligned}
\underset{P(\theta | \mathbb{D})}{\text{maximize}} &&& P(\mathbb{D} | \theta) P(\theta), \\
\text{subject to} &&
& \theta \sim P(\theta | \mathbb{D}), \\
&& \mathbb{D} &= \{(x_1, y_1), \dots, (x_N, y_N) \}.
\end{aligned}
\]









Bayesian Inference


\[
\begin{aligned}
\underset{P(\theta | \mathbb{D})}{\text{maximize}} && \prod_{j=1}^{N} \mathcal{N}&(\| F(x_j; \theta) -  y_j \| \; | \; 0, s_1) \mathcal{N}(\| \theta - \theta_0 \| \; | \; 0, s_2), \\
\text{subject to} &&
& \theta \sim P(\theta | \mathbb{D}), \\
&& \mathbb{D} &= \{(x_1, y_1), \dots, (x_N, y_N) \}.
\end{aligned}
\]









Bayesian Inference


\[
\begin{aligned}
\underset{z}{\text{maximize}} && \mathcal{L}(\mathbb{D},z) &= \mathbb{E}_{\theta \sim Q} \left[\ln(P(\mathbb{D} \mid \theta)P(\theta)) - \ln(Q(\theta;z)) \right], \\
\text{subject to} &&
& \theta \sim Q(\theta;z), \\
&& \mathbb{D} &= \{(x_1, y_1), \dots, (x_N, y_N) \}.
\end{aligned}
\]








Variational Inference: approximates the posterior \(P(\theta | \mathbb{D})\) with a pre-selected distribution \(Q(\theta; z)\)
Objective: collect \(N_\theta\) samples from the current posterior \(Q(\theta; z)\) and maximize Elbo \[
\mathcal{L}(\mathbb{D},z) = \mathbb{E}_{\theta \sim Q} \left[\ln(P(\mathbb{D} \mid \theta)P(\theta)) - \ln(Q(\theta;z)) \right]
\]

title: main
main
text:
Uncertainty Modeling

We provide more structure to the variance of the Bayesian controllers




Bayesian NeuralPbc Optimization Problem


\[
\begin{aligned}
    \underset{z}{\text{minimize}} && J(\phi, u^\theta) &= \mathbb{E}_{x_0 \in \mathcal{D}_N}[ \ell( \phi(x_0, u, T), u) ], \\
    \text{subject to} &&
    \mathop{}\!\mathrm{d}x &= \left(
        \begin{bmatrix}\phantom{-}\nabla_p H \\-\nabla_q H \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ \Omega \end{bmatrix} u^{\theta}(x) \right) \mathop{}\!\mathrm{d}t + \nabla_x u(x) \mathop{}\!\mathrm{d}W_t, \\
    && u^\theta &= \Omega^{\dagger}(\nabla_q H  - \nabla_q H_d^\theta),\\
    && \theta &\sim Q(\theta; z), \\
    && p_s &\sim \mathcal{N}(\hat{p}_s, \sigma_p).
\end{aligned}
\]




Objective: maximize Elbo

\[\begin{gather*}
  \mathcal{L}(J,z) = \mathbb{E}_{\theta \sim Q} \left[\ln(P(J \mid \theta)P(\theta)) - \ln(Q(\theta;z)) \right] \\
  P(J | \theta) = \mathcal{N}(J \; | \; 0, s).
\end{gather*}\]

title: main
text:
NeuralPbc: Hybrid System







Passive Smooth System


\[
H\left(  x(t_1) \right) \leq  H\left(  x(t_0) \right) + \int_{t_0}^{t_1} s(u(t), y(t)) \, \text{d}t
\]





¬†





Passive Hybrid System


\[\begin{gather*}
H\left(  x(t_1) \right) \leq  H\left(  x(t_0) \right) + \int_{t_0}^{t_1} s(u(t), y(t)) \, \text{d}t \\
H(x^+) \leq H(x^-)
\end{gather*}\]










NeuralPbc for contact-rich system


\[\begin{aligned}
    \underset{\theta}{\textrm{minimize}}
    & & J(\phi, u^\theta) &= \mathbb{E}_{x_0 \in \mathcal{D}_N}[ \ell( \phi(x_0, u, T), u) ], \\%
    \textrm{subject to}
    & & M(q) &\mathop{}\!\mathrm{d}\dot{q} + h(q, \dot{q}, \theta)\mathop{}\!\mathrm{d}t - \mathop{}\!\mathrm{d}R  = 0,\\%
    & & u^{\theta} &= \Omega^{\dagger}(\nabla_q H  - \nabla_q H_d).%
\end{aligned}\]

title: main
text:
Bayesian NeuralPbc: Hybrid System



NeuralPbc for contact-rich system


\[\begin{aligned}
    \underset{z}{\textrm{minimize}}
    & & & J(\phi, u) = \mathbb{E}_{x_0 \in \mathcal{D}_N}[\ell(\phi(x_0, u^\theta, T), u^\theta)], \\
    \textrm{subject to}
    & & M(q) &\mathop{}\!\mathrm{d}\dot{q} + h(q, \dot{q}, \theta)\mathop{}\!\mathrm{d}t - \mathop{}\!\mathrm{d}R  = 0,\\
    & & u^{\theta} &= \Omega^{\dagger}(\nabla_q H  - \nabla_q H_d^\theta), \\
    & & p_s &\sim \mathbb{U}(p_{min}, p_{max}), \\
    & & \theta &\sim Q(\theta; z).
\end{aligned}\]

\end{align*}\]
Uncertainty in elevation under each spoke \[
p_s \sim \mathbb{U}(0 \textrm{cm}, 2\textrm{cm})
\]

text:

\[\begin{align*}
p_s &\sim \mathbb{U}(0, p_{max})  \\
p_{max} &= [0, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2] \textrm{cm} \\
J_T &= \sum_{t=0}^{T} \| \dot{x}_c^* - \dot{x}_c(t; \theta) \|
\end{align*}\]

title: main
text:
Theoretical Justification
Why does Bayesian Learning result in more robust controllers?

title: main
text:
System Parameter Uncertainty



Scalar control system
Uncertain drift vector field: \(p \sim
\mathcal{N}(\hat{p}, \sigma_p^2)\).
No measurement uncertainty






\[
\Sigma: \quad
\begin{cases}
  \dot{x} &= px + u, \\
  u(x) &= \theta x, \\
  x(0) &= 1.
\end{cases}
\] \[
  x(t) = e^{(p+\theta)t}.
\]

title: main
text:
Performance Index





\[
\Sigma: \quad
\begin{cases}
  \dot{x} &= px + u, \\
  u(x) &= \theta x, \\
  x(0) &= 1.
\end{cases}
\] \[
  x(t) = e^{(p+\theta)t}.
\]


¬†





Quadratic performance index

\(q \geq 0\), \(r > 0\)

\(T\): control horizon



\[
\mathcal{J} = \int_0^T \left( \frac{1}{2}qx(t)^2 + \frac{1}{2}ru(t)^2  \right)dt.
\]

title: main
text:
Infinite-Horizon Best Performance




\[
\mathcal{J} = \int_0^T \left( \frac{1}{2}qx(t)^2 + \frac{1}{2}ru(t)^2  \right)dt.
\] \[
\mathcal{J}_{T \to \infty} = -\frac{1}{4}\frac{q+r \theta^2}{p+\theta}.
\]


¬†




Solve for \(\theta\) that minimizes \(\mathcal{J}_\infty\): \(\theta^\star = g(p) :=
-p -\sqrt{p^2+\frac{q}{r}}\).







Deterministic


\(\theta^\star = g(\hat{p}) := -\hat{p} -\sqrt{\hat{p}^2+\frac{q}{r}}\)





¬†





Probabilistic


\[
\begin{aligned}
f_{\theta^\star}(\theta^\star) &= \frac{1}{\sigma_p \sqrt{2\pi}}\left( \
\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{q}{r{\theta^\star}^2}\right) \right) \\
&\exp{\left\{ -\frac{1}{2\sigma_p^2}\left( \frac{q}{2r\theta^\star} -
\frac{\theta^\star}{2} - \hat{p}  \right)^2  \right\} }
\end{aligned}
\]

title: main
text:
Infinite-Horizon Best Performance







Deterministic


\(\theta^\star = g(\hat{p}) := -\hat{p} -\sqrt{\hat{p}^2+\frac{q}{r}}\)





¬†





Probabilistic


\[
\begin{aligned}
f_{\theta^\star}(\theta^\star) &= \frac{1}{\sigma_p \sqrt{2\pi}}\left( \
\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{q}{r{\theta^\star}^2}\right) \right) \\
&\exp{\left\{ -\frac{1}{2\sigma_p^2}\left( \frac{q}{2r\theta^\star} -
\frac{\theta^\star}{2} - \hat{p}  \right)^2  \right\} }
\end{aligned}
\]

title: main
text:
Conditional Expectation


\[
\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{J} \mid p] =
-\frac{1}{4}\frac{q+r\theta^2}{p+\theta}\left[ \theta^2 \sigma^2 T +
\left(1-e^{2 T (p+\theta)}\right) \left(1+\frac{1}{2}\frac{\theta^2
\sigma^2}{p+\theta}\right) \right]
\]





Proof


Substituting the solution of the SDE into the performance measure yields
\[
\begin{aligned} \mathcal{J} =
        & -\frac{1}{4}\frac{q+r\theta^2}{p+\theta}\left(1 +
        e^{2T(p+\theta)}\right) +
        (q+r\theta^2)\theta\sigma \int_0^T
        e^{(p+\theta)t} \int_0^t e^{(p+\theta)(t-s)}dW_s
        dt \; + \\ &\frac{1}{2}(q+r\theta^2)\theta^2
        \sigma^2 \int_0^T \left( \int_0^t
        e^{(p+\theta)(t-s)} dW_s  \right)^2 dt
\end{aligned}
\]
The conditional expectation of this quantity given the system parameter \(p\) under the distribution induced by the Wiener process may be computed in closed-form using Ito calculus.
\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_W\left[\mathcal{J} \mid p \right] &= -\frac{1}{4}\frac{q+r\theta^2}{p+\theta}\left(1 - e^{2T(p+\theta)}\right) +
        (q+r\theta^2)\theta\sigma\int_0^Te^{(p+\theta)t}\mathbb{E}_W\left[\int_0^t
        e^{(p+\theta)(t-s)} dW_s~\Big\rvert p\right] dt + \\
        &\frac{1}{2}(q+r\theta)^2\theta^2\sigma^2\int_0^T\mathbb{E}_W\left[\left(\int_0^t
        e^{(p+\theta)(t-s)} dW_s \right)^2~\bigg\rvert p\right] dt \\
        &=-\frac{1}{4}\frac{q+r\theta^2}{p+\theta}\left(1 -
        e^{2T(p+\theta)}\right) +
        \frac{1}{2}(q+r\theta^2)\theta^2\sigma^2\int_0^T\left(\int_0^t
        e^{2(p+\theta)(t-s)} ds \right) dt \\
        &=-\frac{1}{4}\frac{q+r\theta^2}{p+\theta}\left(1 - e^{2T(p+\theta)}\right) +
        \frac{1}{2}(q+r\theta^2)\theta^2\sigma^2\int_0^T
        -\frac{1}{2(p+\theta)}\left(1 - e^{2T(p+\theta)}\right) dt \\
        &=-\frac{1}{4}\frac{q+r\theta^2}{p+\theta} \left[ \theta^2 \sigma^2 T +
        \left(1 - e^{2T(p+\theta)}\right) \left(1 +
        \frac{1}{2}\frac{\theta^2\sigma^2}{p+\theta}\right)\right].
\end{aligned}
\]

üüß

title: main
text:

text:

Optimal control parameter a nontrivial function of \(\sigma\) and \(\sigma_p\).
Bayesian learning strikes the right trade-off.

title: main
text:
DiffEqFlux.jl Demo

Learning \(\dot{x} = f(x)\) where \(f\) is a neural network
Regress on MSE between trajectory of \(f\) and data

title: main
text:
NeuralIdaPbc Main Problem

\[\begin{aligned} \underset{\theta}{\text{minimize}} && J(\theta) &= \left\lVert G^{\bot} \left\{ \nabla_{q} H - M_{d}^{\theta}M^{-1} \nabla_{q} H_{d}^{\theta} + J_{2}^{\theta} \left(M_{d}^{\theta}\right)^{-1} p \right\} \right\rVert^2  \\ \text{subject to}  && H_d^{\theta} &= \frac{1}{2} p^{\top} \left( M_{d}^{\theta} \right)^{-1} p + V_{d}^{\theta}(q) \\ && M_d^{\theta}(q) &= \left(M_d^{\theta}(q)\right)^\top \succ 0 \\ && J_{2}^{\theta}(q,p) &= -\left(J_{2}^{\theta}(q,p)\right)^\top \\ && q^\star &= \underset{q}{\arg \min} \, V_{d}^{\theta} (q) \end{aligned}\]






NeuralIdaPbc



Solve nonlinear PDEs using neural networks and SoS polynomials
Surrogates of \(M_d\), \(J_2\), \(V_d\) are constrained by construction










Pinn



Solve nonlinear PDEs using neural networks
Solution surrogates are constrained via penalty term in loss function

title: main
text:
Research Agenda (approx. 20 minutes)

Vision (~5 minutes)

Service robotics needs robust low-level controllers
Drones / AGVs need robust sensing and controllers to perform dangerous tasks.
In 10 years, data-driven synthesis methods will have matured and made robust.

Future Techniques (~10 minutes)

Robustness of GNN-based controllers
Convex Optimization Layers and ADMM on GNNs
Transfer learning to multiple domains (few-shot performance)

Guiding controller synthesis with human-imitation using LLMs
Representation learning


Potential Funding Mechanisms (~5 minutes)

NSF: Foundational Research in Robotics
SBIR / STTR: Currently with Pitch Aeronautics, explore local companies
NIH: Retain and expand biomedical collaboration with BSU / UTD faculty
